{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{more footnotes|date=January 2014}} '''Rashid Lombard''' (born 1951) is known as both a jazz photographer and political photojournalist. Lombard is the CEO of espAfrika, an events management company which he started in 1997. espAfrika is responsible for staging the [[Cape Town International Jazz Festival]], formerly known as the North Sea Jazz Cape Town.
<!-- If you need section use == Section_title == as below -->
==Background ==
Rashid Lombard was born in Port Elizabeth, Eastern Cape, South Africa on 10 April 1951. His family moved to Cape Town in the early 1960s. Lombard trained as an architectural draughtsman and then worked as an industrial photographer for the construction company, Murray and Roberts, before becoming a photojournalist covering Africa, and, particularly, South Africa where he focussed on photographing the rise of the democratic movement.<ref>{{cite web|title=South African History|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/people/rashid-lombard|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref>
==Early career== In the 1980s he worked for the BBC, NBC, AFP and a number of progressive publications such as ''Grassroots'' and ''South''. His work has been part of exhibitions all over southern Africa, including the University of Zimbabwe in 1983 and the [[Staffrider]] exhibitions of 1984 and 1985. In 1985 his work formed part of the exhibition and book, ''South Africa: The Cordoned Heart, Essays by Twenty South African Photographers'', edited by [[Omar Badsha]] and published in New York. He was a member of the ''Vukalisa'' artists' collective which promoted community-based cultural activities.<ref>{{cite web|title=South African History Online|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/people/rashid-lombard|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref>
==Cape Town International Jazz Festival== In the mid 1990s he became station manager at [[Fine Music Radio]], and then programming manager at P4 Smooth Jazz Radio. In 1998 Lombard approached the director of the North Sea Jazz Festival to stage a local festival in Cape Town. This was the start of the Cape Town International Jazz Festival, now in its 14th year. The Mandela Bay Music Festival was launched in Port Elizabeth, his home town, in 2011 with George Benson playing to a 28 000 strong crowd. Similar jazz festivals have been held in Mozambique and Angola and there are plans to expand into the rest of Africa including Namibia, Tanzania and Botswana.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Daily Maverick|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-04-03-maverick-interview-rashid-lombard/#.UXZX4aJmiSo|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref>
The Cape Town International Jazz Festival brings more than 40 musicians to perform over two days attracting in excess of 30 000 people. It has been ranked in 2007 fourth in the world, below Montreaux and New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival and above the North Sea jazz Festival. Part of the week-long program focuses on workshops, training and mentoring sessions to develop music appreciation and performance. Top performers at the 2013 festival included the Buena Vista Social Club, Mi Casa, Jimmy Dludlu, Jill Scott, and Gregory Porter.
==Jazz Photography== Lombard has photographed both local and international musicians, and has paid particular attention to recording South African musicians-in-exile like [[Hugh Masekela]], [[Miriam Makeba]] and [[Abdullah Ibrahim]]. In 2010, he contributed to the exhibition at the Duotone Gallery at the Cape Town International Jazz Festival which paid tribute to South African saxophonist, Hugh Masekela.
His book of jazz photographs, ''Jazz Rocks'', was published in 2010 by espAfrika and Highbury/Safika Media. [[James Matthews (writer)|James Matthews]], South African poet and writer, in the foreword to the book observed that "Lombard's collection of photographs...is an ode to South Africa's jazz musicians...Each and every lovingly taken photo displays its empathy with the music and the players. As a photographer I don't think Rashid was ever really objective, he is far too personally engaged with his subjects for that."<ref>{{cite book|last=Lombard|first=Rashid|title=Jazz Rocks|year=2010|publisher=Highbury Safika Media|location=Cape Town|page=12}}</ref>
''Jazz Rocks'' was edited by fellow photographer, [[George Hallett (Cape Town)|George Hallett]], who amongst others has won an award for his photographs of [[Nelson Mandela]] and worked on the [[Nobel Peace Centre]] project. The book chronicles the period from the early 1980s to roughly 2004. It is intended as a tribute to some of the musicians who Lombard has worked with and the important role that music played in the anti-apartheid struggle.
In his own words: "Over the years I have spent so much time backstage that the space behind the music is a part of me. Many of the musicians I photographed were far more than just subjects to me. The musicians became my friends and family. We spent many hours honing our skills and teaching each other the politics of the arts."<ref>{{cite book|last=Lombard|first=Rashid|title=Jazz Rocks|year=2010|publisher=Highbury Safika Media|location=Cape Town|page=94}}</ref>
==Awards==
* 1986 – Awarded study and travel grant by the African Arts Fund (USA), to be placed at Magnum Photos, New York. * 1990 – Runner – up to the AFP Picture of the Year Award. * 2000 – SANEC Winner for Small Business Entrepreneur 2000 Award. * 2002 – Arts & Culture Trust Award : Arts Administrator of the Year. * 2002 – Marketer of the Year : Institute of Marketing Management. * 2003 – Winner Cape Town Tourism Award : North Sea Jazz Festival – Cape Town. * 2004 – The Order of the Disa Member : for meritorious service in the interest of the Province of the Western Cape. * 2004 – Khula Arts Award for Music. Contribution to music industry * 2009 – Sekunjalo Top Achievement Award – Top Performer 2009 Media & Finance * 2010 – National Business Award Finalist Top Entrepreneur Award * 2012 – Outstanding and Lifelong contribution to the South African Music Industry: Minister Paul Mashatile and Drakensberg Promotions

[[Image:Robert Vincotte.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Robert Vinçotte.]] '''Robert Vinçotte''' ([[Borgerhout]], 1844-[[Schaarbeek]], 1904) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[engineer]] who laid the basis for industrial [[occupational safety and health|workplace safety]] in his native country. He was involved in the founding of the two companies that would dominate the Belgian [[inspection]] and [[product certification|certification]] market during the twentieth century. He was also the brother of [[Thomas Vinçotte]], a famous Belgian sculptor. ==Early years== Vinçotte was born in [[Antwerp]]. His father was Jean-Henri Vinçotte (1807-1890), a man who started out as a communal teacher but eventually, through studies in [[Catholic University of Leuven (1834–1968)|Leuven]] and [[Liège (city)|Liège]], became first a professor in [[Antwerp]], then [[Ghent]], and ended his career as a high school inspector (a function that was brand new and very prestigious at the time). Vinçotte Sr. was a highly respected man, once described as "la personnification du devoir et du devoir austère. Ses inspections étaient conduites de la façon la plus consciencieuse"Quoted in Jaumotte, page 11. Translation: ..."the personification of duty and austere duty. His inspections were performed in the most meticulous way". Robert Vinçotte also attended school in Liège and in 1865, gaining the titles of "ingénieur honoraire des mines" (honorary [[History of coal mining#Belgium|mining]] engineer) and "docteur en sciences physiques et mathématiques" (doctor in physical and mathematical sciences). In addition, he was allotted a post as a mathematics teacher at the AtheneumIn Belgium, the term "Atheneum" refers to a secondary school organised by the state, in opposition to those schools linked to [[Catholicism]] of Brussels, a great honour in those days. While teaching, Vinçotte deepened his explorations of the explosion of [[Boiler (steam generator)|steam boilers]]. In 1872 Maurice Urban, a director of the [[National Railway Company of Belgium]], asked him to take charge of a new organisation, which would be created for the purpose of inspecting steam boilers in factories. At the time, Vinçotte expressed the problem the new association (and the whole of the industrialized world) faced as follows:
Les explosions de chaudières sont l'un des côtés fâcheux de notre situation industrielle. Désastreuses par les dégâts et les chômages qu'elles occasionnent, odieuses en ce qu'elles montrent la vie humaine pesant moins dans la balance que les dépenses préventives, elles sont, avec les autres dangers du travail, l'une des causes le plus actives à la désaffection des ouvriers.Quoted in Lecocq, page 2. Translation: "Steam boiler explosions are one of the regrettable aspects of our industrial environment. Disastrous because of the damage and unemployment they cause, hateful because they show human life as less expensive than preventive spending, they are, together with the other dangers of work, one of the most biggest causes of disaffected workers".
Vinçotte went on to point out that, whereas in [[Great Britain]] there was on average one explosion for every 6000 boilers in service, for Belgium this rate was one in 1000 to 1200. He identified the main causes for this discrepancy as construction or design errors, coupled with bad maintenance, and concluded that regular inspections, as they were being performed in Britain, could decrease the number of boiler explosions in Belgium with at least 75 percent. ==Director of the association== [[Image:Report Front.jpg|thumb|left|120px|Front of a handwritten inspection report, addressed to Robert Vinçotte]] In August that year, 13 captains of industry and engineers gathered and set up the provisional organisation that they named the "[[Vinçotte (company)#Association Vinçotte|Association pour la surveillance des chaudières à vapeur]]" ("Association for the Surveillance of Steam Boilers"). Its purpose was to prevent [[Boiler (steam generator)|steam boilers]] from exploding through safety inspection and to promote a more efficient use of power. In return for a membership fee, it would provide semiannual safety inspections and staff instruction. According to the introductory letter, the association was non-profit.
Fondée dans un but philantropique, l'Association a exclu l'idée de faire des bénéfices; les ressources de l'Association seront entièrement consacrées à rendre le service aussi complet que possible.Quoted in Lecocq, page 4. Translation: "Founded for a [[philanthropic]] purpose, the association has excluded the notion of making profit; the resources of the association will be entirely devoted to giving the most complete service possible.
[[Image:Report Middle.jpg|thumb|right|120px|Middle of the same inspection report. Note the underlined big "Explosion de 1895" in the middle.]] The association had near to five hundred members by the end of 1872. By 1910, it would inspect more boilers than the combined inspection organisations of Germany and France.Lecocq, page 10 However, this success was still far away at the time: in 1873, the association only had three engineers at its disposal, one of whom was its director, Robert Vinçotte, himself. In that year, Vinçotte combined his function of director with inspecting 250 steam boilers (half of the number of steam boilers the association had registered at the end of the previous year). Vinçotte went abroad the next years, to [[Düsseldorf]] and the [[United States]], to follow the latest innovations in [[steam engine|steam engine and vessel]] technology. In 1875, he pressed the Belgian government to make inspections such as his company performed obligatory by law, something that resulted in the revised police regulations of 1884. Vinçotte's close cooperation with the state would continue in 1881 when he travelled to the United States again, this time on request of the Belgian government {{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} to bring back knowledge of the safety measures for steam boilers of the [[Gilded Age#Industrial and technological advances|burgeoning American industry]]. The result was a compilation of rules for calculating the [[reliability engineering|reliability]] and strength of the key parts of steam boilers, later published in a textbook. Also in 1881, the association announced that, after ten years, its amount of biannually inspected steam boilers had more than quadrupled, while only 0.17 percent of them had failed in the same period. For these and his earlier contributions to Belgian industrial safety, Vinçotte was awarded the rank of Knight in the [[Order of Leopold II]] in 1885. In 1887, a budget surplus allowed every one of its employees a life insurance, a fund that could also be accessed upon retirement. ==Death== Robert Vinçotte died in 1904 after returning from a study trip to [[Italy]], and would be replaced as a director of AV in 1909 by his son, whose first name was the same as his. He is buried in [[Schaarbeek]]. In that same year,{{which|date=December 2016}} AIB was given its second golden medal for its participation at the [[World's fair|world exhibition]] in [[Paris]]. As a tribute, the "Association pour la surveillance des chaudières à vapeur" would be rebaptised in 1922 as "Association Vinçotte pour la surveillance des chaudières à vapeur", as it had already been known for some time abroad. ==Notes== ==See also== *[[Vinçotte (company)]] *[[Destructive testing]] *[[Nondestructive testing]] *[[Product certification]] *[[Reliability Engineering]] ==References== All references are to texts written in French. *de Brouwer, J. "Allocution de Baron J. de Brouwer". ''Association des Industriels de Belgique a.s.b.l.: 1890-1940''. Brussels: AIB, 1940. *Lecocq, L. "Historique de l'Association Vinçotte". De Bruycker, 1922. ==External links== *[http://www.vincotte.be/Frontmodules/EN/home.asp?lang=EN Vinçotte] is the result of the fusion (in 1989) between the two competing organisations (Association Vinçotte and Association des Industriels Belges) Robert Vinçotte was involved in. *[http://www.ceoc.org/ CEOC] is the International Confederation of Inspection and Certification Organisations, and wholly embodies the international approach to security that Robert Vinçotte practiced in his own lifetime. {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vincotte, Robert}} [[Category:Belgian mining engineers]] [[Category:Belgian businesspeople]] [[Category:1844 births]] [[Category:1904 deaths]] [[Category:University of Liège alumni]] [[Category:Flemish people]] [[Category:People from Antwerp]] [[Category:Knights of the Order of Leopold II]] [[Category:19th-century Belgian engineers]]

{{subst:[[Template:Prod|prod]]|''the person named in this articles does not want to be shown here''}}{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=July 2017}} {{notability|Biographies|date=July 2017}} {{Orphan|date=August 2017}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Sahade, Roberto | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|05|29|mf=yes}} | birth_place = {{flag|Brazil}} [[Santos, São Paulo|Santos]] | nationality = Brazilian | occupation = Founder Managing Partner of GMR Energia | education = Civil Engineering FAAP - MBA Ibmec | children = Carolina
Eduardo }} '''Roberto Sahade''' (born May 29, 1976) is a Brazilian business man, founder of GMR Energia group, a family corporation, with investments in power generation in Latin America, mainly Brazil, Chile and Perú. Of Lebanese descent, he is the son of Moukbel Roberto Sahade, Brazilian entrepreneur in construction and real estate development sectors, and Ana Maria Spina Sahade, dentist. Graduated as civil engineer at Fundação Armando Alváres Penteado – FAAP, in 1998, and obtained his MBA from IBMEC-SP, in 2001. Has also done postgraduate studies at Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, in 2007, and at the Stanford Graduate School of Business, in 2011 and 2017, both in the United States, and Insead, Fontainebleau Campus, in 2009, in France. Currently, is in charge of GMR Energia (2004), holding company with investments in CPFL Renováveis, in Brazil, and LAP – Latin America Power, in Chile and Peru.{{Ref|BTG_Pactual|1}}{{Ref|Economia|2}} ==Career== Before graduating as a civil engineer, had already joined the family business activities. After founding the GMR group, started the expansion of the business in real estate, 1998, and in renewable power generation, 2004. In 2007 created ERSA, currently CPFL Renováveis, publicly traded company on [[Bovespa]], in partnership with Pátria Investimentos, Eton Park, Bradesco and DEG (KFW), and moreover, joined BTG Pactual. This company today is the largest renewable power generation in Latin America, with small [[Hydropower|hydro]], wind, [[biomass]] and solar technologies. Was in charge until the end of 2011. This same year, 2011, founded LAP – Latin America Power, a renewable power company with operations in Chile and Peru, corporation capitalized by the former partners BTG Pactual and Pátria/Blackstone. Was in charge until the June 2017.{{cite web |url=http://clipping.interclipnet.com.br/interclipping1/site/interna.php?secao=SaladeImprensa¬icia=1039 |title=BTG e Pátria são parceiros em energia (Valor Econômico - SP) |date=May 11, 2015 |work=INTERCLIPNET |language=portugués |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518102640/http://clipping.interclipnet.com.br/interclipping1/site/interna.php?secao=SaladeImprensa¬icia=1039|archivedate=2015-05-18}}{{cite web |url=http://www.economiaynegocios.cl/noticias/noticias.asp?id=99901 |title=Grupo brasileño invertirá en Chile US$ 2 mil mills. en energía |date=Aug 28, 2012}}{{cite web |url=https://exame.abril.com.br/mercados/oferta-da-cpfl-renovaveis-pode-chegar-a-r-1-2-bi/ |title=Oferta da CPFL Renováveis pode chegar a R$ 1,4 bi |date=Jun 27, 2013}}{{cite web |url=https://gestion.pe/impresa/brasilena-lap-holding-amplia-proyectos-hidroelectricos-peru-2052229/ |title=Brasileña LAP Holding amplía proyectos hidroelectricos en Perú |date=Nov 21, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://economia.estadao.com.br/noticias/geral,cpfl-negocia-fusao-no-setor-de-energias-renovaveis,63144e/ |title=CPFL negocia fusão no setor de energias renováveis |date=Apr 16, 2011}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *http://www.economiaynegocios.cl/noticias/noticias.asp?id=194885 *https://www.law360.com/articles/767344 *https://gestion.pe/impresa/lap-evalua-invertir-proyectos-energia-2011988 *https://gestion.pe/impresa/lap-pondra-operar-dos-minicentrales-este-ano-2091543 *https://exame.abril.com.br/negocios/cpfl-renovaveis-incorpora-dobreve-energia-e-eleva-capacidade-em-18-5/ {{DEFAULTSORT:Sahade, Roberto}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Santos, São Paulo]] [[Category:Brazilian businesspeople]]

{{Infobox video game |title = SeaWorld Adventure Parks Tycoon | image = SeaWorld Adventure Parks Tycoon.jpg | developer = [[DR Studios|Deep Red Games]] | publisher = [[Activision Value|Activision]] | designer = | engine = | released = October 22, 2003 | genre = [[Business simulation game|Business Simulation]] | modes = Single player | platforms = [[Windows]] }} '''''SeaWorld Adventure Parks Tycoon''''' is a [[business simulation game|business simulation]] [[Windows]] [[Video game|game]] based on the SeaWorld parks that was released in 2003. It was published by [[Activision Value|Activision]] and developed by [[DR Studios|Deep Red Games]]. It had a sequel, ''SeaWorld Adventure Parks Tycoon 2'', released in 2005 (2006 in Europe).
==Overview==
The game puts the player in the position of managing [[SeaWorld]] parks from a 2.5D (isometric) perspective. (The [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], and [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]] parks.) It features two different modes of play. One is a mode where the player must complete certain tasks in the park (often pre-built) before moving on. The second is a sandbox mode where the player starts building their own park out of the given barren land and a certain budget. In this mode, there are no limitations to what a player can and cannot do within the park grounds.
==Reception== In the United States, ''SeaWorld Adventure Parks Tycoon'' sold 290,000 copies and earned $5.4 million by August 2006, after its release in September 2003. It was the country's 69th best-selling computer game between January 2000 and August 2006. Combined sales of all ''SeaWorld Adventure Parks Tycoon'' computer games released between January 2000 and August 2006 had reached 450,000 units in the United States by the latter date.<ref name=edgesales>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017165955/http://www.edge-online.com/features/top-100-pc-games-21st-century/ |url=http://www.edge-online.com/features/top-100-pc-games-21st-century/ |title=The Top 100 PC Games of the 21st Century| author=''Edge'' Staff | date=August 25, 2006 |work=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] |archivedate=October 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Sequel== ''SeaWorld Adventure Parks Tycoon 2'' was released January 25, 2005.

{{Infobox member of the Knesset |image= Plato sharon.jpg |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1930|1|18|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Łódź]], [[Poland]] |Year of Aliyah = 1975 |death_date = |death_place = |Knesset(s) = [[Israeli legislative election, 1977|9]] |party1 = [[Development and Peace (political party)|Development and Peace]] |partyyears1 = 1977–1981 }}
'''Shmuel "Samy" Flatto-Sharon''' ({{lang-he-n|שמואל פלאטו-שרון}}, born 18 January 1930) is a controversial [[France|French]]-[[Israel]]i businessman, radio talk-show host and former politician who was a member of the [[Knesset]] between 1977 and 1981.
==Biography== Flatto-Sharon was born as '''Shmuel Sheibitz''' to a Jewish family in [[Łódź]], [[Poland]] in 1930. His family escaped to France after the [[German invasion of Poland]], with Shmuel disguised as a girl.<ref>[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1159193370598&pagename=JPArticle%2FShowFull One on One with Flatto-Sharon: Broadcast Zionism] The Jerusalem Post, 4 October 2006</ref> Forty members of his family, including his father, died in the [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]]. He attended high school in [[Paris]] and [[Strasbourg]], and joined the [[Mouvement Jeunes Communistes de France|Young Communist League]] in 1945.
At age 14, he began selling cigarettes to soldiers and students, and then entered the recycling business, making a fortune in the recycling of paper, rags, and scrap metal. At age 21, he entered the real estate business. Throughout his 20s, Sharon built up his business empire. He came to own a transport service for hauling merchandise with dozens of trucks, industrial plants, a chain of restaurants and cafes, and hotels.<ref name=hayom>http://www.israelhayom.co.il/site/newsletter_article.php?id=25609</ref> By the late 1960s, he owned dozens of companies throughout Europe, the [[United States]], and [[South America]], and did business in oil, logging, and precious metals in [[Africa]].
==Emigration to Israel== In 1975 he made [[aliyah]] to Israel, fleeing the French authorities as he was wanted for embezzling $60 million.<ref name=NYT>[https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/28/world/israel-court-orders-candidate-to-begin-a-bribery-jail-term.html?n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fSubjects%2fE%2fEthics Israel Court Orders Candidate To Begin a Bribery Jail Term] New York Times, 28 June 1984</ref> He bought a villa in [[Savyon]] and immediately launched a business career in Israel. He entered a partnership with Israeli businessman Avraham Pilz, with whom he established the [[Dizengoff Center]], which was Israel's first shopping mall.
==Israeli political career== Despite barely speaking Hebrew, in 1977 he formed a one-man [[List of political parties in Israel|party]], also named [[Development and Peace (political party)|Flatto-Sharon]], to run in the [[Israeli legislative election, 1977|Knesset elections]] that year, hoping to obtain parliamentary immunity to avoid extradition to France.<ref name=FS>[http://www.flattosharon.co.il/BRING%20BACK%20FLATTO-SHARON.html Bring Back Flatto-Sharon] Shmuel Flatto-Sharon</ref>
The list won 2% of the vote, enough for two seats. However, as it was a one-man list, only one seat was taken.<ref>[https://www.knesset.gov.il/description/eng/eng_mimshal_res9.htm Ninth Knesset] Knesset website</ref> It has been suggested that the surprising level of support that the party won was a response to France's refusal to extradite [[Abu Daoud]], who was wanted in Israel for the [[Munich massacre]].<ref name=FS/>
Once ensconced in the [[Knesset]], Flatto-Sharon joined [[Menachem Begin]]'s coalition, with one of his first acts being to vote in favour of a law that prohibited the extradition of Israeli citizens.<ref name=FS/> He sat on the Economic Affairs Committee and in 1978 he renamed the party ''Development and Peace''.<ref>[https://www.knesset.gov.il/faction/eng/FactionHistoryAll_eng.asp Mergers and Splits Among Parliamentary Groups] Knesset website</ref> During his Knesset term he was involved in negotiations to free Israeli [[Prisoner of war|POWs]].<ref name=FS/> The party ran in the [[Israeli legislative election, 1981|1981]] and [[Israeli legislative election, 1984|1984 elections]], but did not pass the [[Election threshold|electoral threshold]] of 1% in either, and subsequently disappeared. Flatto-Sharon was never extradited to France to serve the five-year sentence given to him in his absence, as the five-year statute of limitations had expired.
In 1984 he was sentenced to three months community service for bribery during the 1977 election campaign. It had emerged that he had "bought votes in 1977 by promising apartments to young couples and homes to others at reduced prices" as well as paying voters (who were described as "campaign workers") and giving money to a local party in [[Dimona]] to be associated with his party. His community service was performed in a state agency in Tel Aviv.<ref name=NYT/>
==Later life== After losing his seat in the Knesset in 1981, he returned to private business. He and his wife Annette became celebrities known for hosting parties in their luxury villa in Savyon, with businessmen and other celebrities attending. The French government continued to maintain an international arrest warrant for him, and due to this, he rarely left Israel. In the early 1990s, after learning that he no longer had an [[Interpol]] warrant out for his arrest, Sharon flew to [[Italy]] on a business trip, and was arrested upon arrival in [[Rome]]. Facing possible extradition to France, he escaped back to Israel disguised as a woman. Sharon eventually paid a large fine to settle his criminal case with the French authorities.<ref name=hayom/>
Flatto-Sharon is now an established multi-millionaire and works as a radio talk-show host; his show, named ''Flatto Bli Heshbon'' (Flatto without accountability) is broadcast on numerous stations, including Radius 100, Lev HaMedina, Radio Haifa and Radio Darom FM.<ref>[http://flattosharon.co.il/sommaire-US.htm Biography] Shmuel Flatto-Sharon</ref> He has been married three times, and has two children. His daughter Hilda is a homeopathic doctor, and his son Yoav is a businessman.<ref name=hayom/>
==See also== * [[List of Israeli public officials convicted of crimes or misdemeanors]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.flattosharon.co.il/}} * {{MKlink|id=564}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Flatto-Sharon, Shmuel}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century French criminals]] [[Category:Development and Peace (political party) politicians]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:French emigrants to Israel]] [[Category:French Jews]] [[Category:French people of Polish-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Israeli businesspeople]] [[Category:Israeli people convicted of bribery]] [[Category:Israeli people of French-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Israeli people of Polish-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Israeli politicians convicted of corruption]] [[Category:Israeli radio personalities]] [[Category:Jewish Israeli politicians]] [[Category:Members of the 9th Knesset (1977–81)]] [[Category:People from Łódź]] [[Category:Polish emigrants to France]] [[Category:Polish Jews]] [[Category:Israeli politicians convicted of crimes]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox brewery |name = Super Bock |image = [[File:Super bock.png|200px]] |location = [[Custóias, Leça do Balio e Guifões|Leça do Balio]], Portugal |owner = [[Unicer|Unicer Bebidas de Portugal, SGPS, SA]] |opened = 1927 | url = [http://www.superbock.pt/global/en/ www.superbock.pt/global/en] |active_beers = {{brewbox_beer|name=Super Bock Original|style=[[Pale Lager]]}} {{brewbox_beer|name=Super Bock Stout|style=[[Stout]]}} {{brewbox_beer|name=Super Bock Classic|style=Strong Pale Lager}} {{brewbox_beer|name=Super Bock Abadia|style=[[Wheat Beer]]}} {{brewbox_beer|name=Super Bock Green|style=Lemon flavoured beer}} {{brewbox_beer|name=Super Bock Sem Álcool|style=[[Non-alcoholic beer]]}} {{brewbox_beer|name=Super Bock Selecção 1927|style=Range of [[craft beers]]}} {{brewbox_beer|name=Super Bock Mix|style=Super Bock Mix Vodka Limão and Super Bock Mix Caipirinha}} }}
'''Super Bock''' is a Portuguese beer brand from the '''[[Unicer]]''' brewery<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.superbock.pt/global/en/products/#super-bock-original|title=Super Bock: Characteristics|publisher=Official Website}}</ref> which produces a range of beers under the same name. Established in 1927, Super Bock maintains a leading position in the market and it is among the favourite beer brands of the Portuguese. It is also the best-selling Portuguese beer in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dn.pt/arquivo/2005/interior/super-bock-lidera-ranking-de-bebidas-em-portugal-611658.html|title='Super Bock' leads 'ranking' of drinks in Portugal|language=Portuguese|date=March 7, 2005|publisher=Diário de Notícias|accessdate=November 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marktest.com/wap/a/n/id~1d54.aspx|title=Super Bock maintains the leadership in the space occupied in linear|language=Portuguese|date=June 17, 2014|publisher=Marktest|accessdate=November 13, 2015}}</ref>
== History == Super Bock was created in 1927 and, in 1967, its first adverts were launched under the slogan "The beer that goes beyond your expectations".<ref name="Super Bock - Unicer">{{cite web|url=http://www.unicer.pt/en/home-en/brands/beer/super-bock-en#76|title=Brands – Beer: Super Bock|publisher=Unicer Official Website}}</ref> During the 70s, the company launched a distribution network in [[Lisbon]] with 12 delivery vans.<ref name="Super Bock - Unicer"/>
In 1992, Super Bock became the market leader in Portugal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sbbsdev.com/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=7070&Itemid=74|title=Case Study: Super Bock|language=Portuguese|date=2008|publisher=Superbrands Portugal}}</ref> maintaining the preference of beer consumers until today. In 1995, Super Bock was the first Portuguese brand to use product naming in a music festival. Thus, [[Super Bock Super Rock]] came to be<ref>{{cite web|url=http://superbocksuperrock.pt/en/history/|title=History|publisher=Super Bock Super Rock Official Website}}</ref> the biggest rock festival to be held in Portugal and the only one to celebrate 20 consecutive years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/empresas/detalhe/super_bock_super_rock_celebrara_em_lisboa_os_seus_20_anos_de_musica_estival.html|title=Super Bock Super Rock Festival celebrates 20 years in Parque das Nações|language=Portuguese|date=December 3, 2014|publisher=Negócios|accessdate=November 26, 2015}}</ref> In 1998 and 2001, Super Bock sponsors two of the largest Portuguese cultural events ever: [[Expo'98]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parqueexpo.pt/conteudo.aspx?lang=ing&id_object=692&name=EXPO%2798|title=History: World Expo’98|publisher=Parque Expo Official Website}}</ref> and Porto 2001 ([[European Capital of Culture]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://videos.sapo.pt/ePjGHnqGPbY8EIzZazaC|title=2001 Year Review – Porto Capital of Culture|language=Portuguese|date=August 2, 2012|publisher=SIC|accessdate=November 26, 2015}}</ref>
'''Super Bock Stout''', launched in 2003, sold five million litres with three months of market presence, the value the group estimated to achieve by the end of that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/empresas/detalhe/super_bock_stout_atinge_objectivos_de_vendas_anuais_em_tres_meses.html|title=Super Bock Stout reaches annual sales targets in three months|language=Portuguese|author=Bárbara Leite|date=May 21, 2003|publisher=Negócios|accessdate=November 26, 2015}}</ref> That same year, the brand entered the segment of non-alcoholic beers with '''Super Bock Twin'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvi24.iol.pt/unicer/ferreira-de-oliveira/super-bock-vai-lancar-cerveja-sem-alcool|title=Super Bock will launch non-alcoholic beer|language=Portuguese|date=March 2, 2005|publisher=TVI 24|accessdate=November 26, 2015}}</ref> The following year, 2004, '''Super Bock Green''' was launched,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/empresas/detalhe/unicer_investe_3_milhoes_no_lancamento_da_nova_super_bock_green.html|title=Unicer invests 3 million in the launch of the new Super Bock|language=Portuguese|author=Paula Brito|date=April 5, 2004|publisher=Negócios|accessdate=November 26, 2015}}</ref> marking the beginning of a new segment in the beer market in Portugal: ''beer mixers'' (flavoured beers).
In 2006, two new beers are launched: '''Super Bock Tango''', the first "[[Redcurrant|gooseberry]] beer" produced in Portugal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2006/03/23/Unicer_lan_a_cerveja_com_groselh/|title=Unicer launches beer with gooseberry|language=Portuguese|author=Rita Gonçalves|date=March 23, 2006|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=November 27, 2015}}</ref> and '''Abadia''', a craft beer recipe<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvi24.iol.pt/portugal/europa/abadia-e-maior-sucesso-de-lancamento-da-unicer|title=Abadia is the most successful release of Unicer|language=Portuguese|author=Catarina Craveiro|date=March 23, 2006|publisher=TVI 24|accessdate=November 27, 2015}}</ref> – which achieved the highest market share among new releases.
In 2007, Super Bock presented the first Portuguese beer bottle made entirely of aluminium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2007/02/27/Super_Bock_em_alum_nio_/|title=Super Bock in aluminium|language=Portuguese|author=Victor Jorge|date=February 27, 2007|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> In the same year, the new range of non-alcoholic Super Bock beers – created through a partnership with the [[Chemical Engineering]] Department of [[Faculdade de Engenharia da Universidade do Porto|Porto University's Faculty of Engineering]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sigarra.up.pt/feup/pt/noticias_geral.ver_noticia?p_nr=6687|title=Unicer and FEUP have unique beer production process without alcohol|language=Portuguese|date=April 2007|publisher=FEUP Official Website}}</ref> – was relaunched. The production of the new '''Non-Alcoholic Super Bock''' begins with a base beer – '''Super Bock Original''' – from which the [[aroma]]s are removed. It is then subjected to a process of alcohol removal and, in the end, flavours are returned to the beer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meiosepublicidade.pt/2007/05/Para_que_serve_a_Super_Bock_P_ss/|title=What is the purpose of Super Bock Peach|language=Portuguese|author=Filipe Pacheco|date=May 4, 2007|publisher=Público|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> Also a '''Non-alcoholic Black''' beer and a '''Non-alcoholic beer with Peach flavour''' were launched.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dinheirodigital.sapo.pt/news.asp?id_news=76610|title=Unicer wants to grow 25% in the non-alcoholic beers this year|language=Portuguese|date=January 23, 2007|publisher=Dinheiro Digital|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref> In October, the launch of '''Super Bock Non-Alcoholic Lemon''' reinforces the range of Unicer non-alcoholic beers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2007/10/26/limo-refora-aposta-sem-lcool-da-super-bock/|title=Lemon reinforces Super Bock beers without alcohol|language=Portuguese|author=Victor Jorge|date=October 26, 2007|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref>
In 2008, '''Abadia Ruby and Gold''' beers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvi24.iol.pt/superbock/gourmet/super-bock-lanca-campanha-para-novas-cervejas-por-3-milhoes|title=Super Bock launches new beers campaign for 3 million|language=Portuguese|date=March 20, 2008|publisher=TVI 24|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref> – gourmet limited editions – were launched, the same year when '''Super Bock XpresS''' bottle<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2008/06/03/super-bock-a-pressao-renasce-em-garrafa/|title=Draught Super Bock now in bottle|language=Portuguese|author=Rita Gonçalves|date=June 3, 2008|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref> was announced – a pressure bottled beer, a partner product of the pressure beer system for domestic use (Super Bock XpresS) that had been put on the market in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meiosepublicidade.pt/2006/11/Super_Bock_lan_a_cerveja_press/|title=Super Bock launches draught beer for home use|language=Portuguese|author=Maria João Lima|date=November 15, 2006|publisher=Meios&Publicidade|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref> During 2008, the brand began a process of restyling of its entire range.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.superbrands.com/pt/pdfs/vol5_case_studies/SUPERBOCK.pdf|title=Case Study: Super Bock|language=Portuguese|date=2009|publisher=Superbrands Portugal}}</ref>
'''Super Bock Mini''' with easy opening – a pioneering system, which eliminates the need of a corkscrew<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2009/05/29/super-bock-mini-com-capsula-inovadora/|title=Super Bock Mini with innovative capsule|language=Portuguese|author=Rita Gonçalves|date=May 29, 2009|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref> – hits the market in 2009. Following this launch, in 2010 begins the sale of the IceBocks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.briefing.pt/marketing/11682-novas-super-bock-verao-e-icebocks-em-edicao-especial.html|title=New Super Bock Verão and Icebocks in special edition|language=Portuguese|date=May 31, 2011|publisher=Briefing|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref> – a box to which ice can be added to cool the mini beers -, and is launched the first edition of '''Super Bock Verão''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/buzz/super-bock-entra-na-onda/|title=Super Bock goes with the flow|language=Portuguese|author=Ana Marcela|date=July 19, 2011|publisher=Dinheiro Vivo|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref> a more refreshing and low-alcohol beer.
Also in 2010 the range of '''Super Bock Non-Alcoholic 0.0%''' has been extended with the launch of a new flavour: Apple. The brand seized this launch to present a new image for its non-alcoholic flavoured beers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2010/05/12/super-bock-sem-alcool-e-com-sabor-a-maca/|title=Non-Alcoholic Super Bock with a taste of apple|language=Portuguese|date=May 12, 2010|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref>
The big focus in 2011 was the launch of '''Super Bock Classic'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meiosepublicidade.pt/2011/05/super-bock-regressa-as-origens-com-nova-cerveja/|title=Super Bock returns to his roots with new beer|language=Portuguese|author=Pedro Durães|date=May 4, 2011|publisher=Meios&Publicidade|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref> In 2012 Super Bock went through a market repositioning process, creating a new brand signature: "Life is Super".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicer.pt/en/home-en/unicer/history|title=Over a hundred years of history|publisher=Unicer Official Website}}</ref>
In 2013, '''Super Bock Selecção 1927''' was launched,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.distribuicaohoje.com/Super-Bock-lanca-Seleccao-1927/|title=Super Bock launches Selecção 1927|language=Portuguese|author=Ana Rita Costa|date=April 30, 2013|publisher=Distribuição Hoje|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.essenciadovinho.com/pt/revista-wine/read/548-super-bock-reforca-gama-de-cervejas-artesanais-seleccao-1927|title=Super Bock reinforces range of craft beers with Selecção 1927|language=Portuguese|date=July 25, 2013|publisher=Essência do Vinho|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref> a range of craft beers in limited and seasonal editions.
In 2015, the best-selling Portuguese beer in the world took on a new commitment with Portuguese consumers, and changed its signature to "Super Bock takes Friendship Seriously".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://imagensdemarca.sapo.pt/temas-especiais/radar/super-bock-leva-a-amizade-a-serio/|title=Super Bock takes Friendship seriously|language=Portuguese|author=Ana Gaboleiro|date=April 17, 2015|publisher=Imagens de Marca|accessdate=December 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://marketeer.pt/2015/04/20/super-bock-quer-mais-brindes-a-amizade/|title=Super Bock wants more toasts to friendship|language=Portuguese|date=April 20, 2015|publisher=Marketeer|accessdate=December 9, 2015}}</ref> At the same time, Super Bock launched a new range of beers – '''Super Bock Mix Vodka Lemon''' and '''Super Bock Mix Caipirinha''' – in order to meet the needs of urban consumers, and focusing on night markets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/buzz/vodka-limao-ou-caipirinha-a-super-bock-da-a-provar-as-duas/|title=Vodka lemon or caipirinha? Super Bock releases the two|language=Portuguese|date=May 15, 2015|publisher=Público|accessdate=December 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meiosepublicidade.pt/2015/05/super-bock-agora-com-vodka-limao-e-caipirinha/|title=Super Bock now with Vodka Lemon and Caipirinha|language=Portuguese|author=Rui Oliveira Marques|date=May 5, 2015|publisher=Meios&Publicidade|accessdate=December 9, 2015}}</ref>
In January 2016, Unicer opened the visitor centre "Super Bock House of Beer", located in Leça do Balio Production Centre.<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://marketeer.pt/2016/01/18/super-bock-inaugura-casa-dedicada-a-cerveja/|title=Super Bock opens house dedicated to beer|language=Portuguese|date=January 18, 2016|accessdate=March 30, 2016|publisher=Marketeer}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.meiosepublicidade.pt/2016/01/casa-da-cerveja-da-super-bock-no-porto-com-assinatura-da-omdesign/|title=Super Bock House of Beer in Porto made by Omdesing|language=Portuguese|author=Pedro Durães|date=January 18, 2016|accessdate=March 30, 2016|publisher=Meios&Publicidade}}</ref> There you can see the brewing process, discover the raw materials used to make beer, as well as stories, interesting facts and remarkable moments of Super Bock beer.<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2016/01/19/super-bock-inaugura-casa-da-cerveja-no-porto-com-imagens/|title=Super Bock opens House of Beer in Porto|language=Portuguese|author=Rita Gonçalves|date=January 19, 2016|accessdate=March 30, 2016|publisher=Hipersuper}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|URL=https://imagensdemarca.sapo.pt/atualidade/super-bock-abre-as-portas-da-casa-da-cerveja/|title=Super Bock opens House of Beer|language=Portuguese|author=Marco Silva|date=January 18, 2016|accessdate=March 30, 2016|publisher=Imagens de Marca}}</ref>
== Internationalization == [[File:Super Bock Luanda.jpg|thumb|250px|Outdoor in [[Luanda]], Angola.]] Super Bock beer has a cult status among English football supporters; many discovered it during the [[UEFA Euro 2004]] championship in Portugal. However, its history with the supporters of [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] goes back into the early 1990s thanks to matches against teams like [[FC Porto|Porto]] in the [[UEFA Champions League]] and [[Boavista F.C.|Boavista]] in the [[2001–02 UEFA Champions League]].
Currently, Super Bock has been strongly committed to internationalization,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.porto24.pt/cidade/exportacoes-da-unicer-compensaram-quebras-no-mercado-interno/|title=Exports of Unicer offset falls in domestic market|language=Portuguese|date=March 22, 2012|publisher=Porto 24|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref> especially in European countries (including France<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvi24.iol.pt/portugal/cerveja/super-bock-espera-crescer-10-nas-vendas-em-franca|title=Super Bock expects to grow 10% in sales in France|language=Portuguese|date=April 24, 2009|publisher=Público|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref> and England<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/empresas/detalhe/unicer_expande_se_em_inglaterra_vendas_internacionais_crescem_13_em_2001.html|title=Unicer expands in England; International sales grow 13% in 2001|language=Portuguese|author=Nuno Carregueiro|date=October 26, 2001|publisher=Negócios|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref>) and Portuguese speaking countries (namely [[Brazil]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtp.pt/noticias/economia/unicer-comeca-a-produzir-super-bock-no-brasil-em-dezembro_n688733|title=Unicer starts producing Super Bock in Brazil in December|language=Portuguese|date=October 17, 2013|publisher=RTP|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref> [[Angola]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marketeer.pt/2015/01/12/saca-facil-da-super-bock-angola-com-nova-campanha/|title=Super Bock Angola "Saca Fácil" with new campaign|language=Portuguese|date=January 12, 2015|publisher=Marketeer|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dn.pt/bolsa/interior/unicer-envia-120-milhoes-de-litros-de-cerveja-para-angola-1727126.html|title=Unicer sends 120 million litres of beer to Angola|language=Portuguese|date=December 4, 2010|publisher=Diário de Notícias|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref> and [[Mozambique]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://imagensdemarca.sapo.pt/atualidade/super-bock-lanca-primeira-campanha-publicitaria-em-mocambique/|title=Super Bock launches first campaign in Mozambique|language=Portuguese|author=Luís Lopes|date=November 19, 2014|publisher=Imagens de Marca|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref>), establishing itself as the best-selling Portuguese beer in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sabado.pt/dinheiro/detalhe/fino_ou_garrafa_125_anos_a_fazer_cerveja.html|title=Draught or bottle? 125 years of brewing|language=Portuguese|author=Tiago Carrasco|date=April 26, 2015|publisher=Sábado|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref>
The main export market continues to be Angola,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2009/02/26/unicer-fornece-95-das-cervejas-portuguesas-importadas-por-angola/|title=Unicer provides 95% of Portuguese beers imported by Angola|language=Portuguese|author=Victor Jorge|date=February 26, 2009|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=December 18, 2015}}</ref> where the group's best-selling brand beer is Super Bock.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/buzz/interior.aspx?content_id=3886483|title=Unicer launches new campaign for Cristal Mini Easy Opening in Angola|language=Portuguese|author=Paula Brito|date=April 1, 2014|publisher=Dinheiro Vivo|accessdate=December 18, 2015}}</ref>
In 2014, Super Bock extends its export market to Arab countries, with the arrival of the first containers with half a million liters of Super Bock Non-Alcoholic 0.0% to [[Saudi Arabia]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/fazedores/super-bock-chega-a-arabia-saudita-sem-alcool-e-com-sabor-a-limao-maca-e-roma/|title=Super Bock comes to Saudi Arabia without alcohol and with lemon, apple and pomegranate flavours|language=Portuguese|date=May 4, 2007|publisher=Público|accessdate=August 26, 2013}}</ref> – thanks to a dealcoholisation process that does not stop the fermentation stage and allows the preservation of the beer's essential characteristics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvi24.iol.pt/portugal/cervejas/unicer-apresenta-terca-feira-processo-de-desalcoolizacao|title=Unicer introduces Tuesday dealcoholisation process|language=Portuguese|date=April 9, 2007|publisher=TVI 24|accessdate=December 18, 2015}}</ref> After entering the market of Saudi Arabia with Super Bock Non-Alcoholic beers, Unicer now wants to expand its presence in the Middle East.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sol.pt/noticia/107310|title=Super Bock beer for Muslims|language=Portuguese|author=Sara Ribeiro|date=June 6, 2014|publisher=Sol|accessdate=December 18, 2015}}</ref>
==Brands== According to a brand flavours' diversification strategy, Super Bock beer is currently available in several varieties in the Portuguese market,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.superbock.pt/global/en/products/|title=Your Beer|publisher=Official Website|accessdate=December 9, 2015}}</ref> including: * '''Original''' (5.2% ABV): [[Lager]] beer. * '''Sem Álcool''': Non-alcoholic variant – Non-alcoholic [[pilsner]] (0.0% AVB) and Non-alcoholic black (<0.45% AVB). * '''Classic''' (5.8% ABV): Strong lager beer. * '''Abadia''' (6.4% ABV): Beer with extra fermentation of red tone. * '''Stout''' (5% ABV): Black beer. * '''Green''' (2% ABV): Beer with lemon juice. * '''Super Bock Selecção 1927''': Range of craft beers. * '''Super Box Mix''': available in two varieties – Super Bock Mix Vodka Limão and Super Bock Mix Caipirinha. * Only available in Export markets: '''0.0% Non-Alcoholic Super Bock''' (also available in four flavours: Lemon, Apple, Pomegranate, Strawberry & Dates).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.briefing.pt/marketing/30521-isto-e-super-bock-sem-alcool-0-0.html|title=This is 0.0% Non-Alcoholic Super Bock|language=Portuguese|date=August 4, 2014|publisher=Briefing|accessdate=December 9, 2015}}</ref>
== Distinctions == Super Bock was the first Portuguese beer to receive the Quality Certificate by SGS ICS (International Certification Services).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sgs.pt/en/Our-Company/About-SGS/SGS-in-Brief/SGS-in-Portugal.aspx|title=SGS in Portugal|publisher=SGS Official Website}}</ref>
Super Bock range has about 68 gold awards in the international competition Monde Selection de la Qualité, since 1977, between Great Gold Medals and Gold Medals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2015/04/08/bebidas-da-unicer-distinguidas-internacionalmente/|title=Pedras and Super Bock recognized abroad|language=Portuguese|author=Ana Catarina Monteiro|date=April 8, 2015|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lifestyle.publico.pt/noticias/303347_ouro-para-a-super-bock-e-a-agua-das-pedras|title=Gold for Super Bock and Pedras Water|language=Portuguese|author=Margarida Martins|date=April 13, 2012|publisher=Público|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> Presently, Super Bock Original sums up 32 consecutive gold medals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://epicur.pt/super-bock-pedras-com-galardoes-internacionais/|title=Super Bock and Pedras with international awards|language=Portuguese|publisher=Epicur|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> Super Bock Stout was awarded 10 times: one Grand Gold Medal, six Gold Medals and three Silver Medals. Super Bock Green has one Grand Gold Medal, two Gold Medals and two Silver Medals. The Abadia variety, launched in 2006, won its first medal in its first participation (2007).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipersuper.pt/2007/06/19/super-bock-recebe-quatro-monde-selection/|title=Super Bock receives four Monde Selection|language=Portuguese|author=Rute Gonçalves Marques|date=June 19, 2007|publisher=Hipersuper|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.briefing.pt/comunicacao/16073-marcas-da-unicer-ganham-seis-medalhas-no-monde-selection-de-la-qualite.html|title=Unicer brands win six medals at Monde Selection de la Qualité|language=Portuguese|date=April 11, 2012|publisher=Briefing|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref>
In 2005, Super Bock won two awards in the 1st edition of the Advertising Effectiveness Awards and got the best result ever in terms of [[notability]], according to data presented to the jury of the Effectiveness Awards. Super Bock Green Campaign by Tempo OMD won the gold award. Launched in 2004, this beer created a new segment in the beverage market in Portugal – the flavoured beers – thus constituting a challenge for the company and bringing a new dynamic to the category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meiosepublicidade.pt/2005/11/Quem_s_o_os_mais_eficazes/|title=Who are the most effective|language=Portuguese|author=Maria João Lima|date=November 21, 2005|publisher=Meios&Publicidade|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref>
Unicer Beers – Super Bock and Carlsberg – were distinguished by activation campaigns at point of sale, during the 1st edition of POPAI Awards. In total, Super Bock and Carlsberg received nine awards, specifically four gold, three silver and two bronze trophies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.briefing.pt/marketing/18526-unicer-marcas-de-cerveja-premiadas-nos-popai.html|title=Unicer: beer brands awarded in POPAI|language=Portuguese|date=October 23, 2012|publisher=Briefing|accessdate=December 10, 2015}}</ref>
== Sponsorships == Super Bock sponsors<ref>{{cite web|url=https://imagensdemarca.sapo.pt/atualidade/super-bock-e-fantasporto/|title=Super Bock and Fantasporto|language=Portuguese|author=Sandra Barata|date=February 11, 2013|publisher=Imagens de Marca|accessdate=December 11, 2015}}</ref> Porto Film Festival, ''[[Fantasporto]]'', since 1989.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fantasporto.com/home|title=Fantasporto|publisher=Fantasporto Official Website}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publico.pt/culturaipsilon/noticia/estado-vai-distinguir-fantasporto-com-a-medalha-de-merito-cultural-1215620|title=Portuguese government will distinguish Fantasporto with Cultural Merit Medal|language=Portuguese|date=February 13, 2005|publisher=Público|accessdate=December 11, 2015}}</ref>
Super Bock was the brand responsible for the activation of summer festivals in Portugal, with the launch in 1995 of [[Super Bock Super Rock]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.rtp.pt/blogs/superbocksuperrock/artigos/super-bock-super-rock-desde-1995/|title=Super Bock Super Rock since 1995|language=Portuguese|author=Telma Teixeira|date=June 28, 2013|publisher=RTP|accessdate=December 10, 2015}}</ref> – a festival that from its beginning attracted some of the most prestigious bands and solo performers to Portugal, to act on national stages and even Spanish and Angolan stages. In 2015, the festival returns to Lisbon, celebrating its 20th anniversary in [[Parque das Nações]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publico.pt/culturaipsilon/noticia/super-bock-super-rock-instalase-em-2015-no-parque-das-nacoes-1678290|title=Super Bock Super Rock settles at Parque das Nações in 2015|language=Portuguese|author=Ana Rute Silva|date=December 3, 2014|publisher=Público|accessdate=December 10, 2015}}</ref>
In addition to Super Bock Super Rock, the Super Bock brand is present in major festivals and musical events that take place in Portugal. It is also the official beer of various regional celebrations, at north and south of the country<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dn.pt/bolsa/interior/festivais-de-musica-e-o-futebol-sao-estrategicos-1900909.html|title=Music festivals and football are strategic|language=Portuguese|date=July 8, 2011|publisher=Diário de Notícias|accessdate=December 10, 2015}}</ref> – in [[Viana do Castelo]], [[Ponte de Lima]], [[Porto]], Lisbon, among many others. Super Bock is also a close brand to the students with the sponsor of major academic events, at national level.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.univercidade.net/uni/vida-academica/as-10-razoes-pelas-quais-vais-querer-ter-a-festa-extraordinaria-na-tua-universidade/#estudar|title=Top 10 reasons why you'll want to have an EXTRAORDINARY party at your university!|language=Portuguese|date=September 30, 2014|publisher=Rede UniverCidade|accessdate=December 10, 2015}}</ref>
In 1998, Super Bock was the official sponsor of [[Expo'98]] (1998 Lisbon World Exhibition),<ref name="Super Bock - Unicer"/> one of the largest Portuguese events, which attracted about 11 million visitors and was considered the best World Exhibition ever by BIE (the intergovernmental organization in charge of overseeing and regulating World Expos).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/iol-push/expo-98-a-obra-que-fez-portugal-acreditar|title=Expo 98: the work that made Portugal believe|language=Portuguese|author=Cláudia Costa|date=May 22, 2013|publisher=TVI 24|accessdate=December 11, 2015}}</ref> In 2001, the brand sponsors the Porto 2001 ([[European Capital of Culture]]),<ref name="Super Bock - Unicer"/> committing once again to the promotion of cultural events.
In 2009, the first edition of the National Creative Industries Prize was promoted,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industriascriativas.com/|title=National Creative Industries Prize|language=Portuguese|publisher=National Creative Industries Prize Official Website}}</ref> a pioneering initiative in Portugal, organized by Unicer, today associated with Super Bock, and [[Serralves]] Foundation,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.serralves.pt/en/creative-industries/pnics/|title=Creative Industries: National Creative Industries Award|publisher=Serralves Official Website}}</ref> which seeks to receive, evaluate and distinguish Portuguese products, services and brands that contribute to economic and social development of the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/Imprimir.aspx?content_id=4386658|title=Creative Industries. The Innovation Prize is to be able to grow accompanied|language=Portuguese|author=Mariana de Araújo Barbosa|date=February 7, 2015|publisher=Dinheiro Vivo|accessdate=December 11, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://uaonline.ua.pt/pub/detail.asp?c=41511|title=Creative Industries National Prize Super Bock/Serralves & Next Big Idea|language=Portuguese|date=February 6, 2015|publisher=Aveiro University Online Newspaper|accessdate=December 11, 2015}}</ref>
In 2012, Super Bock was the official sponsor of the 7 Wonders – Beaches of Portugal initiative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.briefing.pt/marketing/15205-super-bock-patrocina-7-maravilhas-praias-de-portugal.html|title=Super Bock sponsors 7 Wonders – Beaches of Portugal|language=Portuguese|date=February 8, 2012|publisher=Briefing|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref>
Super Bock has also strongly backed sports through the sponsorship of football teams such as [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting CP]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://expresso.sapo.pt/economia/super-bock-rende-se-ao-futebol=f556687|title=Super Bock surrenders to football|language=Portuguese|author=Catarina Nunes|date=January 8, 2010|publisher=Expresso|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref> [[FC Porto]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://economico.sapo.pt/noticias/retorno-mediatico-da-super-bock-cresce-20-com-aposta-no-futebol_200388.html|title=Media return of Super Bock grows 20% with focus on football|language=Portuguese|author=Elisabete Felismino|date=August 29, 2014|publisher=Económico|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref> and [[C.F. Os Belenenses|Clube de Futebol "Os Belenenses"]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/empresas/media/detalhe/super_bock_patrocina_belenenses_ateacute_2012.html|title=Super Bock sponsors Belenenses until 2012|language=Portuguese|author=Filipe Pacheco|date=August 28, 2009|publisher=Negócios|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref>
== External links == *[https://www.facebook.com/SuperBock/ Facebook] *[https://twitter.com/superbock Twitter] *[https://www.instagram.com/superbock/ Instagram]

'''TÜSİAD''', the '''Turkish Industry and Business Association''' ({{lang-tr|Türk Sanayicileri ve İş İnsanları Derneği}}), is [[Turkey|Turkey's]] top business organization.
Founded in 1971, TÜSİAD is a voluntary, independent, non-governmental organization dedicated to promoting public welfare through private enterprise. TÜSİAD promotes principles of participatory democracy, a competitive market economy, environmental sustainability, and universal freedoms and human rights. The Association supports independent research and policy discussions on important social and economic issues in Turkey and abroad. TÜSİAD is composed of CEOs and executives from major industrial and services companies in Turkey, including Fortune 500 companies. The current Chairman is Erol Bilecik and the Secretary-General is [[Bahadir Kaleagasi]].
== About == TÜSİAD represents more than 4,000 member companies which represent half of the Turkey's value-added; 80% of Turkey’s total foreign trade volume; more than 50% of private sector employment; and 80% of corporate tax revenue.
== Structure == TÜSİAD headquarters are in Istanbul and there are seven representative offices: Ankara, Brussels, Washington, D.C., Paris, Berlin, Beijing and London.
TÜSİAD's activities are structured around round tables led by members of the board of directors and 36 working groups.
TÜSİAD partners with the [[Brookings Institution]], the [[German Marshall Fund of the United States]], and [[St. Petersburg International Economic Forum]] (SPIEF).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tusiad.org/tr/tusiad/isbirlikleri|title=İşbirlikleri|website=tusiad.org|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref>
TÜSİAD is a member of the [[Business and Industry Advisory Committee to the OECD|Business and Industry Advisory Committee to the OECD (BIAC)]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://biac.org/our-members/|title=Our Members|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Global Business Coalition,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globalbusinesscoalition.org/gbc-members/|title=Global Business Coalition Members|last=|first=|date=|website=www.b20coalition.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref> and [[Confederation of European Business|BusinessEurope]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businesseurope.eu/members|title=Members of BusinessEurope|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Media References == In June 2016, TÜSİAD released a statement criticizing a proposed law which would enhance the government’s authority to appoint boards of trustees to companies.The controversial article was later removed from the law.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sozcu.com.tr/2016/ekonomi/kayyum-duzenlemesi-degistirildi-1282408/|title=Kayyum düzenlemesi değiştirildi|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref>
Turkish President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] has criticized TÜSİAD on multiple occasions. In April 2015, Erdoğan was critical of comments made about the Turkish economy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/Default.aspx?pageID=238&nID=80923&NewsCatID=345|title=Turkish President Erdoğan slams TÜSİAD chairwoman over economy remarks - BUSINESS|website=Hürriyet Daily News {{!}} LEADING NEWS SOURCE FOR TURKEY AND THE REGION|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref> In December 2014, Erdoğan criticized the organization for apparently side-stepping his office after then TÜSİAD President Haluk Dinçer explained the organization works with the prime minister and ministers whose business is related to the organization’s efforts, not the president.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/tusiad-a-muhatap-resti-27863705|title=TÜSİAD’a muhatap resti|newspaper=Hürriyet|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref>
==Presidents== * 1971–1979 [[Feyyaz Berker]] * 1980–1984 [[Ali Koçman]] * 1985 [[Şahap Kocatopçu]] * 1986 [[Sakıp Sabancı]] * 1987–1988 [[Ömer Dinçkök]] * 1989–1990 [[Cem Boyner]] * 1991–1992 [[Bülent Eczacıbaşı]] * 1993–1996 [[Halis Komili]] * 1997–1998 [[Muharrem Kayhan]] * 1999–2000 [[Erkut Yücaoğlu]] * 2001–2003 [[Tuncay Özilhan]] * 2004–2006 [[Ömer Sabancı]] * 2007–2009 [[Arzuhan Doğan Yalçındağ]] * 2010–2013 [[Ümit Nazlı Boyner]] * 2013–2014 {{Interlanguage link multi|Muharrem Yılmaz|tr}} * 2014–2015 Haluk Dinçer * 2015–2017 Cansen Başaran–Symes * 2017–Present Erol Bilecik
== External links == * http://www.tusiad.org/ * http://www.tusiad.us

{{EngvarB|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{refimprove|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox university |name = Universiti Teknologi Malaysia |native_name = {{nobold|{{native name|ms|Universiti Teknologi Malaysia}}
{{native name|zh|马来西亚工艺大学|italics=off}} }} |image_name = UTM-LOGO-FULL.png |image_size = 200px |caption = |latin_name = |motto = Kerana Tuhan Untuk Manusia{{cite web|title=Emblem and Motto|url=http://www.utm.my/about/emblem-and-motto/|publisher=UTM|accessdate=12 August 2014}} |mottoeng = In the Name of God for Mankind |established = 14 March 1972 |closed = |type = [[Public university|Public]] [[research university]] |affiliation = |endowment = |officer_in_charge = |chairman = |chancellor = [[Raja Zarith Sofia]] |president = |vice-president = |superintendent = |provost = |vice_chancellor = Professor Datuk Ir. Dr. Wahid Omar |rector = |principal = |dean = |director = |head_label = |head = |faculty = 2,624{{cite web|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/universities/universiti-teknologi-malaysia|title=Universiti Teknologi Malaysia Top Universities|publisher=Quacquarelli Symonds(QS)|accessdate=7 March 2017}} |staff = |students = 18,030 (2015){{cite web|url=http://www.utm.my/about/facts-and-figures/|title=Facts and Figures - About UTM|publisher=Universiti Teknologi Malaysia (UTM)|accessdate=7 March 2017}} |undergrad = 10,236 (2015) |postgrad = 7,794 (2015) |doctoral = |other = |city = [[Skudai]], [[Iskandar Puteri]] |state = [[Johor]] |province = |country = [[Malaysia]] |coor = |campus = |former_names = Technical School (1904–1941)
Technical College (1942–1971)
Institut Teknologi Kebangsaan (1971–1975) |free_label = |free = |sports = |colors = |colours = |nickname = |mascot = |athletics = |affiliations = [[Association of Commonwealth Universities|ACU]], [[Association of Southeast Asian Institutions of Higher Learning|ASAIHL]], [[Federation of the Universities of the Islamic World|FUIW]],{{cite web |url=http://www.fuiw.org/universities.php?l=1&p=1&cc=my |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050126075634/http://www.fuiw.org/universities.php?l=1&p=1&cc=my |archivedate=26 January 2005 |df=dmy-all }} [http://apucen.usm.my/ APUCEN] |website = {{URL|http://www.utm.my/}} |logo = |footnotes = }} [[Image:UTM maingate.jpg|thumb|Main entrance]] '''Universiti Teknologi Malaysia''' (also known as '''UTM''') is a public research-intensive university in engineering, science and technology located in [[Skudai]], [[Johor]] and it has a branch campus in [[Kuala Lumpur]]. UTM is a graduate-focused university with 56% of its student population consisting of postgraduate students, the highest in Malaysia. As of 2015, UTM has more than 5,000 international students from more than 120 countries, the highest research university in Malaysia. ==History== === From a technical school === The history of UTM began in 1904 when a technical school began operation on Weld Road (now Jalan Raja Chulan) to teach Technical Assistants for the Federated Malay States Departments of Railways, Survey and Public Works. The school was known as '''Treacher Technical School''' , named after Sir [[William Treacher]], the Resident General. Students took classes on part-time basis; they worked and trained according to the technical needs of their employment. In 1941 the Advisory Committee of Technical Schools recommended that the school be elevated to college status and proposed that a new technical college be constructed. The new college was to be built on a 47-acre piece of government land in Gurney Road (now Jalan Semarak), Kuala Lumpur. Plans for the construction of the college, however, were put on hold when [[World War II]] erupted in Peninsular Malaysia. === Then a technical college === In the early years, the technical college conducted engineering courses at [[diploma]] level in Civil Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Electrical and Radio Engineering, Land Surveying, Building Architecture and Quality Surveying, while a special in Automobile Engineering was offered for the transportation enforcement officers. The enrolment for the 1958/1959 academic session was 320 students. In 1960 the college began a new era by upgrading its [[engineering]] courses to the [[academic degree|degree]] level. Student following courses at the college sat for [[professional examinations]] conducted by the Institution of Civil Engineers and Institution of Mechanical Engineers, United Kingdom & the Royal Institute of British Architects, as well as the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors. Students for the professional courses were drawn from government servants for the Federation of Malaya Singapore, Borneo and Brunei. Minimum entry requirements then were Grade I & II in the Cambridge School Certificate or the Malayan School Certificate with credits in English Language & Basic Mathematics. Priorities were given to those who obtained credits in Science subjects. === A technical institute === On March 14, 1972, Malaysia’s Ruler, DYMM Seri Paduka Baginda Yang Dipertuan Agong proclaimed the formation of Institut Teknologi Kebangsaan (ITK) under section 6(1) of the [[University & University College Act 1971]]. The institution inherited all the amenities and facilities of the former Technical College of Gurney Road. Mr. [[Ainuddin Abdul Wahid]] who was the principal of Technical College was made the first Rector of ITK. An interim Council consisting of nine members was tasked to devise the major policies to be implemented in the new establishment. Three administrative positions were also formalized: the [[Registrar (education)|Registrar]], the [[Bursar]] and the [[Chief Librarian]]. === Finally a university === On 1 April 1975, the journey from school to university was completed when the institution became '''Universiti Teknologi Malaysia''' (UTM). In 1976, the government approved the university constitution and the university Senate and Council were established. As of the 1975/1976 academic year, the [[UTM Faculty of Engineering]] split into the faculties of [[Civil engineering|Civil]], [[Mechanical engineering|Mechanical]] and [[Electrical engineering|Electrical]] Engineering Faculties. The three faculties together with the Faculty of [[Built Environment]] and Faculty of [[Surveying]], plus the Centre for Science for Science Students and Centre for Humanities Students became the precursors of most academic programmes in UTM today. By 1976, the student population had reached 2,593 with 1,745 pursuing diploma level studies, 607 in the degree programmes, and 241 in the integrated programmes. On December 3, 1977, UTM witnessed its first group of 65 graduates being conferred their degrees in the inaugural convocation ceremony in Kuala Lumpur, graced by the Royal Highness Almarhum Sultan Ismail Ibni Almarhum Sultan Ibrahim, the first Chancellor of UTM. === Moving to Johor === The university moved to a new campus located on 2,400 acres of land in [[Skudai]], Johor. Construction works had begun in 1978 and the campus opened on September 16, 1985 by His Majesty [[Sultan Iskandar Ibni Almarhum Sultan Ismail]], then the [[Yang di Pertuan Agong]], in his capacity as his capacity as the second Chancellor of UTM. UTM's has regional and international academic collaborations., including [[Intel]], [[Altera]], and [[Proton (automobile)|Proton]].http://www.innovation.utm.my/collaborations-in-innovation/utm-proton-in-green-tech/ UTM-Proton to Collaborate in developing hybrid and green technology UTM is one of the few public universities in Malaysia that has attained [[research university]] status, opening avenues for research and industrial collaboration through government research grants. === Full autonomy === On 8 January 2012, the [[Malaysian Ministry of Higher Education]] declared UTM to be the first Malaysian university to attain full autonomy from the government. This allows the university to select the best of the regional students, as well as handle most of the management internally for a more efficient administration. ==Campuses== UTM has two campuses - the main campus is in [[Skudai]], and was the first university in the state of [[Johor]]. It has an area of 1148 hectareshttp://www.sps.utm.my/download/bahan2015/Postgraduate%20brochure%20SRAD%202015.pdf A Guide to Postgraduate Study ([http://web.utm.my/campus_map/ campus map]), and is the second largest public university after [[Universiti Putra Malaysia]] (UPM). It is about 20 km north of the state capital, Johor Bahru. The branch campus is situated in ''Jalan Semarak'' within [[Kuala Lumpur]], with an area of 38 hectares. The branch campus accommodates [[diploma]] students, part-time students (also known as the ''SPACE'' program), undergraduate students (Malaysia-Japan International Institute of Technology) and foreign students taking business courses. == General == The university has a library (known as ''Perpustakaan Sultanah Zanariah'')http://www.utm.my/psz/ Homepage of Perpustakaan Sultanah Zanariah with online facilities. There are free bus services, as well as local and international restaurants on campus. The Webometrics Ranking of World Universities places UTM in the fourth place in the South East Asia Region, and the top in Malaysia.{{Cite web |url=http://www.webometrics.info/top100_continent.asp?cont=SE_Asia |title=Webometric Rankings of Universities in South East Asia |access-date=13 August 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705123840/http://www.webometrics.info/top100_continent.asp?cont=SE_Asia |archive-date=5 July 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In the QS University Rankings, it placed 100 in the "''Engineering & Technology Universities''" category among other world ranked universities in 2016[http://www.topuniversities.com/universities/universiti-teknologi-malaysia-utm Ranking of UTM at topuniversities.com] UTM aims to achieve the status of a global university and rank among 50 of the world's best universities by 2020.{{cite web|last=Bernama|title=UTM Strives to be Among World's Top 50 Universities|url=http://www.malaysiandigest.com/news/38607-utm-strives-to-be-among-worlds-top-50-universities.html|work=Malaysian Digest}} Another initiative is the formation of the Iskandar Malaysia Academic Partnership (IMAP) resulting from the Inaugural UTM University Presidents Forum. == Official Song == UTM official song entitled 'Keunggulan Terbilang' (Distinct Eminence) was composed by Hamzah Ibrahim. The lyrics was written by Tamjis Kastiran.http://www.utm.my/about/utm-official-song/ ==Residential colleges (Skudai Campus)== UTM has on-campus hostel blocks that provide accommodation for students. The hostel blocks are grouped into units known as colleges, for simplifying administration. Each college has three or more hostel blocks under their administration. UTM has 13 colleges, which can accommodate 17,500 students. Among the facilities provided at each residential college are a cafeteria, a multipurpose hall, a Muslim prayer room, tennis courts, an internet and computer center, a convenience store and a common room.http://www.utm.my/currentstudent/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=76&Itemid=123 Accommodation in UTM UTM can provide accommodation for outsiders, i.e. parents or relatives, visiting friends etc., with Scholar's Inn @ UTM JB and Scholar's Inn @ UTM KL. The Scholar’s Inn @ UTMKL is a city campus hotel at Jalan Semarak, in the heart of Kuala Lumpur. Located within the Universiti Teknologi Malaysia Kuala Lumpur campus and approximately 10 minutes’ drive from KLCC/ Petronas Twin Towers, the hotel is also within range of tourist spots such as the National Library, National Art Gallery, Istana Budaya and the Golden Triangle. Scholar’s Inn @ UTMKL comprises 56 rooms and studios, a meeting room, a business centre and the Scholar’s Deli. ===Inner ring colleges=== * Kolej Rahman Putra,http://www.utm.my/group/rahmanputra/about/sejarah-kolej-rahman-putra History of Kolej Rahman Putra the first and oldest college. * Kolej Tun Fatimah, the first all-girls college. * Kolej Tun Razak. * Kolej Tun Hussein Onn. * Kolej Tun Dr Ismail. * Kolej Tuanku Canselor. ===Outer ring colleges=== * Kolej Perdana. * Kolej 9. * Kolej 10. * Kolej Datin Seri Endon. * Kolej Tun Ghafar Baba. * [[American Society for Engineering Education]] (ASEE) * [[European Association for International Education]] (EAIE) ===Global outreach programme=== UTM Global Outreach Programme is an international programme designed to develop UTM’s students to be global-ready graduates. ==Research University== The Ministry of Education formed an ad hoc committee, comprising research from Malaysian universities, to formulate a concept paper on the establishment of research universities (RUs). The content of the paper deals with their vision, missions and goals, the criteria and standard for Rus, their governance, prevision of incentives, accreditation concerns, cost implications and an action plan.http://www.utm.my/research/research-university/ ===Research Management Centre=== Research Management Centre was established in 1982. Formerly known as ‘Research and Consultation Unit’ and as ‘Research & Development Unit’ and finally renamed as ‘Research Management Centre’, in 1997. RMC manages research and development activities, intellectual property creation and management, technological development, promotion and exploitation of R&D findings through close collaboration with the Ministry of Higher Education, Ministry of Science, Technology & Innovation, Small and Medium Industry Development Corporation, industry, research institutes, other universities and international organisations. RMC manages funds from research grant schemes available such as Science Fund, Techno Fund, Inno Fund, Fundamental Research Grant Scheme (FRGS), Commercialization of R&D Fund (CRDF), Technology Acquisition Fund (TAF) and Multimedia Grant Scheme (MGS).http://web.utm.my/rmc ===Research fundings=== * MOSTI grants ** Demonstrator Application Grant Scheme (DAGS) ** ScienceFund ** TechnoFund * MOHE grants ** Fundamental Research Grant Scheme (FRGS) ** Exploratory Research Grant Scheme (ERGS) ** Long-term Research Grant Scheme (LRGS) ** Prototype Research Grant Scheme (PRGS) * MOA * UTM grants ** UTM Short Term Grant ** Research University Grant (GUP) ** Institutional Research Grant (Top-Down) * Other Agencies * Contract research ==Rankings== {| width=90% class="wikitable" ! Ei Hnin Khine (Christina Aung), b. 1983 | education = [[Bachelor of Science|B.Sc]] [[Mechanical Engineering]] | parents = | relatives = }} {{Burmese script}} '''Dagon Win Aung''' ({{lang-my|ဒဂုံ ဝင်းအောင်}}) is a Burmese businessman and chairman of the [[Union of Myanmar Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry]] (UMFCCI). He founded [[Dagon International]], a construction company, in the 1990s, with Win Thein, a [[Myanmar Army]] captain.{{cite news|url=http://www2.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=9223|title=Dagon Win Aung: The Importance of Being Well-Connected|last=Wai Moe|date=5 November 2007|publisher=The Irrawaddy|accessdate=16 April 2012}} he has since expanded his business empire, to the timber trade, construction and import-export sectors.{{cite news|url=http://www2.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=14151&page=6|title=Tracking the Tycoons|date=September 2008|accessdate=16 April 2012}} Following [[Cyclone Nargis]] in 2008, his company was awarded with government contracts for various reconstruction projects in the [[Irrawaddy delta]].{{cite news|url=http://election.irrawaddy.org/news/499--junta-backed-usdp-campaigning-through-nargis-projects-.html|title=Junta-backed USDP Campaigning through Nargis Projects|last=Wai Moe|date=7 October 2010|publisher=The Irrawaddy|accessdate=16 April 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Burmese businesspeople]] [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Bago Region]]
